title: Malachi Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Malachi chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Malachi Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Malachi Chapter 2.

questions.question: To whom is the commandment addressed in Malachi 2:1?
options: Priests
Prophets
Kings
Levi
questions.correctAnswer: Priests
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:1 states, 'And now, O ye priests, this commandment is for you,' clearly addressing the priests.

questions.question: What will the LORD do if the priests do not give glory unto His name according to Malachi 2:2?
options: Send a curse upon them
Bless them abundantly
Ignore their actions
Remove them from office
questions.correctAnswer: Send a curse upon them
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:2 says, 'I will even send a curse upon you, and I will curse your blessings,' showing the consequence of not giving glory.

questions.question: What will God corrupt according to Malachi 2:3?
options: Your seed
Your altar
Your offerings
Your garments
questions.correctAnswer: Your seed
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:3 states, 'Behold, I will corrupt your seed,' indicating a punishment on their descendants.

questions.question: Who was the covenant made with, as mentioned in Malachi 2:4?
options: Levi
Judah
Israel
Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: Levi
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:4 explains, 'my covenant might be with Levi,' showing the covenant with the tribe of Levi.

questions.question: What did God give Levi for the fear with which he feared Him, according to Malachi 2:5?
options: Life and peace
Riches and honor
Power and strength
Wisdom and knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Life and peace
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:5 says, 'My covenant was with him of life and peace; and I gave them to him for the fear wherewith he feared me.'

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:6, what was not found in Levi's lips?
options: Iniquity
Lies
Pride
Deceit
questions.correctAnswer: Iniquity
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:6 states, 'The law of truth was in his mouth, and iniquity was not found in his lips.'

questions.question: What should the priest's lips keep according to Malachi 2:7?
options: Knowledge
Wealth
Power
Secrets
questions.correctAnswer: Knowledge
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:7 says, 'For the priest's lips should keep knowledge, and they should seek the law at his mouth.'

questions.question: What have the priests done to the covenant of Levi according to Malachi 2:8?
options: Corrupted it
Kept it holy
Strengthened it
Forgotten it
questions.correctAnswer: Corrupted it
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:8 states, 'ye have corrupted the covenant of Levi,' accusing the priests of corrupting the covenant.

questions.question: Why has God made the priests contemptible according to Malachi 2:9?
options: Because they have not kept His ways
Because they are poor
Because they are strangers
Because they are wise
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have not kept His ways
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:9 explains, 'I have made you contemptible... because ye have not kept my ways.'

questions.question: Who is said to have created all people, according to Malachi 2:10?
options: One God
Many gods
The priests
The kings
questions.correctAnswer: One God
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:10 states, 'hath not one God created us?' emphasizing unity under one Creator.

questions.question: True or False: According to Malachi 2:11, Judah has been faithful and pure in marriage.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:11 says Judah 'hath profaned the holiness of the LORD' and 'hath married the daughter of a strange god,' showing unfaithfulness.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 2:13 describes the altar of the LORD being covered with weeping and crying out.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:13 states, 'covering the altar of the LORD with tears, with weeping, and with crying out.'

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 2:16 says the LORD hates putting away (divorce).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:16 says, 'For the LORD, the God of Israel, saith that he hateth putting away.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Malachi 2:14: 'Yet is she thy companion, and the wife of thy ______.'
options: covenant
heart
kingdom
faith
questions.correctAnswer: covenant
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:14 states, 'Yet is she thy companion, and the wife of thy covenant.'

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:15, why did God make one?
options: That he might seek a godly seed
That he might rule over many
That he might be alone
That he might gain wealth
questions.correctAnswer: That he might seek a godly seed
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:15 says, 'And wherefore one? That he might seek a godly seed.'

medium.title: Malachi Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Malachi Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Malachi 2:2 teach us about obedience and faithfulness in our service to God?
options: God blesses those who ignore His commandments
Ignoring God's commandments brings curses and loss of blessings
Priests can choose which laws to follow
Blessings are guaranteed regardless of obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring God's commandments brings curses and loss of blessings
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:2 clearly states that if the priests do not hear and lay the commandment to heart, the LORD will send a curse and curse their blessings. This teaches the importance of obedience and faithfulness. This is supported by verses 2, 8, and 9, which show consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with discouragement because they feel their prayers are not heard. Based on Malachi 2:13, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God ignores all prayers equally
Tears and weeping at the altar guarantee acceptance
God may not regard offerings when hearts are unfaithful
Only sacrifices matter, not the heart
questions.correctAnswer: God may not regard offerings when hearts are unfaithful
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:13 reveals that God is not pleased with offerings when they are accompanied by insincere tears and weeping, indicating that the condition of the heart matters. This emphasizes sincerity in devotion (verses 13, 8, and 9).

questions.question: What does Malachi 2:6 teach about the character and conduct expected of priests as examples for others?
options: Priests should only focus on sacrifices
Priests should walk in peace and equity, turning many from iniquity
Priests are free from accountability
Priests need not teach the law
questions.correctAnswer: Priests should walk in peace and equity, turning many from iniquity
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that the law of truth was in the priest's mouth and he walked with God in peace and equity, turning many away from iniquity. This shows priests are to be godly examples and teachers (verses 6, 7, and 4).

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:14-15, what is God's perspective on marriage and faithfulness?
options: Marriage is a casual arrangement
Faithfulness in marriage is a covenant witnessed by God
Divorce is encouraged for convenience
Marriage need not be respected
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness in marriage is a covenant witnessed by God
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 15 emphasize that the LORD is a witness between husband and wife, calling marriage a sacred covenant for seeking a godly seed. This underlines the importance of faithfulness and commitment in marriage (verses 14, 15, and 16).

questions.question: How does Malachi 2:16 instruct believers regarding the treatment of their spouses?
options: God hates putting away and calls for faithfulness
Divorce is acceptable in all cases
Spouses should be treated as property
God is indifferent to marriage
questions.correctAnswer: God hates putting away and calls for faithfulness
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that the LORD hates putting away (divorce) and warns against dealing treacherously with one's spouse, encouraging faithfulness and respect in marriage (verses 14, 15, 16).

questions.question: What warning does Malachi 2:8 give about causing others to stumble in faith and conduct?
options: It is acceptable to corrupt the covenant
Leaders must not cause others to stumble in the law
Stumbling in the law is unavoidable
Partiality in the law is encouraged
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must not cause others to stumble in the law
questions.explanation: Verse 8 condemns the priests for departing from the way and causing many to stumble at the law, corrupting the covenant of Levi. This teaches leaders to uphold integrity and guide others rightly (verses 8, 9, and 7).

questions.question: True or False: According to Malachi 2:10, God created all people with one Father and commands us not to deal treacherously with one another.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 reminds us that we have one Father, God, who created us, and it rebukes treachery among brethren, emphasizing unity and faithfulness among God's people.

questions.question: What consequence does Malachi 2:3 mention for those who do not lay God's commandment to heart?
options: They will receive greater blessings
Their seed will be corrupted and they will be taken away
They will be honored among the people
They will be forgiven without repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Their seed will be corrupted and they will be taken away
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states God will corrupt their seed and spread dung upon their faces, indicating severe judgment for disobedience, showing the seriousness of faithfulness (verses 2, 3, 9).

questions.question: How can Malachi 2:7 guide a believer's approach to studying and teaching God's Word?
options: Only priests should know the law
The priest is a messenger who should keep knowledge and seek the law diligently
The law is optional for believers
Knowledge of the law can be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: The priest is a messenger who should keep knowledge and seek the law diligently
questions.explanation: Verse 7 teaches that the priest's lips should keep knowledge and seek the law at his mouth because he is the LORD's messenger. This encourages diligence and reverence in studying and teaching Scripture (verses 6, 7).

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 2:17 shows people complaining that God does not judge evil and wrongly claims that God delights in evildoers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 describes people wearied the LORD by questioning His justice, saying evildoers are good in His sight, which is a false accusation pointing to a lack of trust in God's righteous judgment (verses 17, 2, 8).

questions.question: How does Malachi 2:11 address the issue of faithfulness to God within the community?
options: It praises Israel for faithfulness
It condemns Judah for marrying daughters of strange gods
It encourages mixing with other faiths
It ignores unfaithfulness in marriage
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns Judah for marrying daughters of strange gods
questions.explanation: Verse 11 condemns Judah for profaning the LORD's holiness by marrying the daughter of a strange god, highlighting the importance of faithfulness and purity among God's people (verses 10, 11, 12).

questions.question: In Malachi 2:12, what does the LORD say will happen to those who offer improper offerings and violate His covenant?
options: They will be accepted by God
They will be cut off from the tabernacles of Jacob
They will receive a reward
They will be ignored
questions.correctAnswer: They will be cut off from the tabernacles of Jacob
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches that the LORD will cut off both master and scholar who offer improper offerings and violate His covenant, showing the seriousness of honoring God's commands and covenant (verses 11, 12).

questions.question: What does Malachi 2:4-5 reveal about the covenant with Levi and its intended blessings?
options: The covenant was only about sacrifices
The covenant included life and peace given for the fear of the LORD
Levi was not part of God's covenant
The covenant was meant for punishment
questions.correctAnswer: The covenant included life and peace given for the fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 explain that God's covenant with Levi was of life and peace, granted because of the reverent fear and respect Levi had for God's name, emphasizing the blessings of obedience (verses 4, 5, 6).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Malachi 2:15 says 'And did not he make one? Yet had he the residue of the ______.'
options: spirit
body
faith
law
questions.correctAnswer: spirit
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states 'Yet had he the residue of the spirit,' referring to God's design for one flesh in marriage and the spiritual unity intended, highlighting the importance of godly commitment.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:9, what was the result of the priests not keeping God's ways and showing partiality?
options: They were exalted before the people
They became contemptible and base before all the people
They were rewarded generously
They were ignored by the people
questions.correctAnswer: They became contemptible and base before all the people
questions.explanation: Verse 9 says that because the priests did not keep God's ways and were partial in the law, God made them contemptible and base before all the people, warning of dishonor due to unfaithfulness (verses 8, 9).

hard.title: Malachi Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Malachi Chapter 2.

questions.question: What consequence does the LORD say will come upon the priests if they do not give glory unto His name?
options: He will send a curse upon them and curse their blessings
He will exile them to a foreign land
He will make them leaders of the people
He will give them greater honor among the nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will send a curse upon them and curse their blessings
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:2 states that if the priests do not give glory to God's name, the LORD will send a curse upon them and curse their blessings.

questions.question: In Malachi 2, what does God say He will do to the 'seed' of the priests as a judgment?
options: Corrupt their seed and spread dung upon their faces
Bless their children abundantly
Give them royal lineage
Make their seed priests forever
questions.correctAnswer: Corrupt their seed and spread dung upon their faces
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:3 describes God's judgment as corrupting the priests' seed and spreading dung upon their faces as a sign of disgrace.

questions.question: What covenant is referenced as being with Levi, according to Malachi 2?
options: A covenant of life and peace
A covenant of land and prosperity
A covenant of kingship and rule
A covenant of eternal sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of life and peace
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:5 explains that God's covenant with Levi was one of life and peace, granted because of his fear and reverence for God.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2, what was true about Levi's lips?
options: The law of truth was in his mouth, and iniquity was not found in his lips
He spoke lies and deceived the people
He was silent and did not teach
He only spoke in parables
questions.correctAnswer: The law of truth was in his mouth, and iniquity was not found in his lips
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:6 states that Levi's lips held the law of truth and that iniquity was not found in them, indicating his integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: What role does Malachi say the priest should fulfill in relation to the law?
options: They should keep knowledge and seek the law at his mouth as the messenger of the LORD
They should make new laws
They should only perform sacrifices
They should avoid teaching the law
questions.correctAnswer: They should keep knowledge and seek the law at his mouth as the messenger of the LORD
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:7 describes the priest as a messenger of the LORD whose lips should keep knowledge and from whom the people should seek the law.

questions.question: What is the LORD’s response to the priests’ departure from His ways and corruption of the covenant of Levi?
options: He has made them contemptible and base before all the people
He has exalted them above others
He has blessed them with wealth
He has given them longer life
questions.correctAnswer: He has made them contemptible and base before all the people
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:9 states that because the priests have not kept God's ways and have been partial in the law, He has made them contemptible and base in the eyes of the people.

questions.question: What rhetorical question in Malachi 2:10 emphasizes the unity of humanity under one God?
options: Have we not all one father? Hath not one God created us?
Is not the earth the LORD’s?
Who can stand before God’s anger?
What profit is there in sacrifice?
questions.correctAnswer: Have we not all one father? Hath not one God created us?
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:10 uses this question to highlight that all people share a common origin and that to act treacherously against one another profanes the covenant of their fathers.

questions.question: What abomination does Malachi accuse Judah of committing in Israel and Jerusalem?
options: Marrying the daughter of a strange god
Building altars to Baal
Offering sacrifices to idols
Ignoring the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Marrying the daughter of a strange god
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:11 condemns Judah for profaning the LORD’s holiness by marrying the daughter of a strange god, which was considered an abomination.

questions.question: What consequence will the LORD bring upon the man who marries the daughter of a strange god, according to Malachi 2?
options: He will be cut off from the tabernacles of Jacob
He will be blessed with many children
He will be made a priest
He will inherit the land of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He will be cut off from the tabernacles of Jacob
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:12 declares that the LORD will cut off the man, both master and scholar, who commits this act from the tabernacles of Jacob.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:13, what has been the effect on the LORD of the people's offerings because of their behavior?
options: He regards the offerings no more and does not receive them with good will
He accepts the offerings with joy
He multiplies their offerings
He commands a festival
questions.correctAnswer: He regards the offerings no more and does not receive them with good will
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:13 explains that the people's tears and weeping have covered the altar, causing the LORD not to regard or accept their offerings with favor.

questions.question: In Malachi 2, what does the LORD say about dealing treacherously against the wife of one's youth?
options: The LORD hates putting away and calls for taking heed to your spirit
It is acceptable if done quietly
It is commanded in the law
It brings great blessing
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD hates putting away and calls for taking heed to your spirit
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:16 states that the LORD hates divorce ('putting away') and warns people to take care not to deal treacherously against their wife.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by the statement 'He made one, yet had the residue of the spirit' in Malachi 2:15?
options: The unity and sanctity of marriage designed to produce a godly seed
The creation of the world in seven days
The role of the priesthood in Israel
The covenant with Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: The unity and sanctity of marriage designed to produce a godly seed
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:15 highlights the creation of one flesh and the spiritual purpose behind marriage—to seek a godly offspring, emphasizing covenant fidelity.

questions.question: What accusation do the people make that ‘wearies the LORD’ according to Malachi 2:17?
options: Saying that every one who does evil is good in the sight of the LORD
Claiming that the LORD ignores the wicked
Denying the existence of God
Offering sacrifices insincerely
questions.correctAnswer: Saying that every one who does evil is good in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:17 explains that the people wear out the LORD by claiming that evildoers are good and that He delights in them, thus questioning His justice.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 2 teaches that priests are to be impartial and uphold the covenant of Levi faithfully.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:8-9 rebuke the priests for partiality and failing to keep the covenant of Levi, implying that they should be impartial and faithful.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "For the priest's lips should keep _______, and they should seek the law at his mouth: for he is the messenger of the LORD of hosts."
options: knowledge
power
wealth
silence
questions.correctAnswer: knowledge
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:7 states that the priest's lips should keep knowledge, indicating their role as teachers and messengers of God's law.

theological.title: Malachi Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Malachi Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:2, what consequence does the LORD declare for the priests if they do not give glory to His name?
options: He will send a curse upon them and their blessings
He will reward them with peace and prosperity
He will ignore their prayers
He will remove them from their priestly office
questions.correctAnswer: He will send a curse upon them and their blessings
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:2 clearly states that if the priests do not give glory to God's name, He will send a curse upon them and curse their blessings. This reflects God's holiness and the seriousness of honoring Him, consistent with passages like Numbers 6:24-26 and Ezekiel 44:23-24.

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will do to the seed of the priests who fail to heed His commandment, according to Malachi 2:3?
options: Corrupt their seed and spread dung upon their faces
Bless their descendants abundantly
Give them wisdom to teach His law
Remove them from the sanctuary
questions.correctAnswer: Corrupt their seed and spread dung upon their faces
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:3 describes God's judgment on unfaithful priests by corrupting their seed and spreading dung upon their faces, symbolizing defilement and disgrace. This is consistent with the theme of divine judgment in passages like Deuteronomy 28:16 and Ezekiel 9:4-6.

questions.question: What covenant does the LORD refer to in Malachi 2:4 and 2:5, which He made with Levi?
options: A covenant of life and peace for the fear of the LORD
A covenant of prosperity and long life
A covenant of earthly kingship
A covenant of silence and secrecy
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of life and peace for the fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:4-5 explains that God's covenant with Levi was one of life and peace, given because of Levi's reverent fear of God. This covenant emphasizes God's desire for holiness and peace in His priesthood, paralleling themes in Numbers 25:10-13 and Hebrews 7:22-28.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:6, how did Levi exemplify his priestly role?
options: The law of truth was in his mouth and he turned many away from iniquity
He amassed great wealth and power
He remained silent in the face of sin
He sought political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: The law of truth was in his mouth and he turned many away from iniquity
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:6 highlights Levi's integrity and faithfulness, as he spoke truth and turned people away from sin. This aligns with the ideal priestly role seen in Psalm 15:1-5 and Ezekiel 44:23-24, underscoring holiness and teaching.

questions.question: In Malachi 2:7, what responsibility is assigned to the priests regarding the knowledge of the law?
options: Priests should keep knowledge and seek the law at his mouth
Priests should judge disputes without learning the law
Priests should focus on sacrifices only
Priests should avoid teaching to prevent error
questions.correctAnswer: Priests should keep knowledge and seek the law at his mouth
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:7 teaches that priests are messengers of God who must preserve and impart knowledge of the law, reflecting the responsibility to instruct God's people as seen in Deuteronomy 17:8-11 and James 3:1.

questions.question: What failure of the priests is described in Malachi 2:8 that resulted in causing many to stumble?
options: They departed from the way and corrupted the covenant of Levi
They became wealthy and neglected the poor
They refused to offer sacrifices
They worshiped idols openly
questions.correctAnswer: They departed from the way and corrupted the covenant of Levi
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:8 accuses the priests of abandoning God's way and corrupting the covenant, which caused others to stumble. This failure is echoed in Jeremiah 23:1-4 and Ezekiel 34:1-10, where false shepherds are condemned.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:9, what was the consequence for the priests because they were partial in the law and did not keep God’s ways?
options: They were made contemptible and base before all the people
They were exalted among the nations
They received divine protection
They were given new priestly garments
questions.correctAnswer: They were made contemptible and base before all the people
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:9 states that priests became despised because they were partial and disobedient. This judgment fits the biblical principle that disobedience leads to disgrace, as seen in Isaiah 3:5 and Ezekiel 44:9.

questions.question: Malachi 2:10 asks, 'Have we not all one father? hath not one God created us?' What theological principle is this highlighting?
options: The unity and common origin of all humanity under one God
The division of people into separate divine origins
The superiority of the priestly class
The exclusivity of Israel as God's only creation
questions.correctAnswer: The unity and common origin of all humanity under one God
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:10 emphasizes that all people share one Creator and Father, underscoring human unity and opposing treachery among brethren. This principle is foundational in scriptures like Acts 17:26 and Galatians 3:28.

questions.question: What sin of Judah is denounced in Malachi 2:11, involving marriage?
options: Marrying the daughter of a strange god, profaning the holiness of the LORD
Marrying only within their own tribe
Refusing to marry altogether
Marrying without priestly approval
questions.correctAnswer: Marrying the daughter of a strange god, profaning the holiness of the LORD
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:11 condemns Judah for marrying foreign women who worship false gods, thereby profaning God's holiness. This parallels warnings in Deuteronomy 7:3-4 and Ezra 9:1-2 about intermarriage leading to idolatry.

questions.question: According to Malachi 2:12, what will the LORD do to the man and scholar who commit the sin of marrying a foreign god’s daughter?
options: He will cut them off out of the tabernacles of Jacob
He will bless them abundantly
He will give them a special revelation
He will make them priests
questions.correctAnswer: He will cut them off out of the tabernacles of Jacob
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:12 states that God will cut off those who commit this sin from the tabernacles of Jacob, a divine judgment emphasizing covenant purity. Similar judgments appear in Joshua 23:12-13 and Ezra 10:11.

questions.question: What is the complaint the people make in Malachi 2:13 about their offerings, and how does the LORD respond?
options: They weep and cry but God no longer regards their offerings with good will
They offer gladly and God is pleased
They do not bring offerings and God is angry
They bring offerings but God multiplies their sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: They weep and cry but God no longer regards their offerings with good will
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:13 describes how the people bring offerings with tears and sorrow, yet God does not accept them with favor because of their insincerity and covenant unfaithfulness. This theme is also found in Isaiah 1:11-17 and Hosea 6:6.

questions.question: In Malachi 2:14-15, what reason does the LORD give for condemning treachery against the wife of one’s youth?
options: Because God is a witness of the covenant and intended for a godly seed
Because marriage is only a civil contract
Because divorce is permitted at will
Because polygamy is commanded
questions.correctAnswer: Because God is a witness of the covenant and intended for a godly seed
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:14-15 stresses that God witnesses the marital covenant and designed marriage to produce a godly offspring, condemning treachery and divorce. This aligns with Genesis 2:24, Matthew 19:4-6, and Ephesians 5:25-33.

questions.question: What attitude toward divorce does God express in Malachi 2:16?
options: God hates putting away and calls it an act of violence
God approves of divorce in all situations
God is indifferent to divorce
God commands divorce frequently
questions.correctAnswer: God hates putting away and calls it an act of violence
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:16 explicitly states that God hates divorce ('putting away') and equates it with violence, emphasizing the sanctity of marriage. This is consistent with Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 19:6-9 and 1 Corinthians 7:10-11.

questions.question: How have the people 'wearied the LORD' according to their words in Malachi 2:17?
options: By saying that evil is good and God delights in it
By worshiping God sincerely
By obeying the law sincerely
By repenting of their sins
questions.correctAnswer: By saying that evil is good and God delights in it
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:17 reveals the people's cynical claim that God approves of evil, which exhausts His patience. This corrupt view is refuted in Psalm 5:4-6, Proverbs 15:9, and Romans 12:9, affirming God’s holiness and justice.

questions.question: What role does Malachi 2:7 assign to the priest as a 'messenger of the LORD of hosts'?
options: To teach knowledge and seek the law at his mouth
To lead military campaigns
To build the temple
To collect taxes
questions.correctAnswer: To teach knowledge and seek the law at his mouth
questions.explanation: Malachi 2:7 describes the priest as a messenger tasked with teaching knowledge and studying the law, reflecting the prophet-priest role seen in Exodus 19:6 and Hebrews 5:1-4.
